Timeline for Post-Quantum Migration According to analysis by Chaincode Labs, Bitcoinâ€™s transition to post-quantum cryptography (PQC) can follow two main strategies: aÂ short-term contingency plan (cf. Figure 1)Â and aÂ long-term comprehensive path (cf. Figure 2).
TheÂ short-term strategyÂ focuses on deploying a basic quantum-resistant option withinÂ 1 to 2 years, offering a fallback mechanism in case cryptographically relevant quantum computers (CRQCs) emerge sooner than expected. This involves proposing a minimal PQC signature scheme through a BIP, implementing it in Bitcoin Core, and enabling voluntary migration of vulnerable UTXOs. While not optimized for all use cases, it provides immediate protection for at-risk users and critical institutions. Success depends on close coordination across the technical community and early involvement from major Bitcoin holders.
TheÂ long-term strategyÂ envisions a broader research and development process to design Bitcoinâ€™s optimal quantum-resistant future. This includes evaluating different PQC algorithms, mitigating their performance trade-offs, and developing robust UTXO migration mechanisms. Drawing from historical upgrades like SegWit and Taproot, which took several years to reach wide adoption, this path could span up to a decade.
Chaincode emphasizes that these two strategies areÂ not mutually exclusive. The short-term plan offers immediate protection and preparedness, while the long-term plan focuses on sustainability, optimization, and ecosystem-wide adoption in the face of evolving quantum threats.
Figure 1. Timeline of estimate to establish short-term contingency measures.
Figure 2. Timeline for comprehensive quantum resistance path.
Government Post-Quantum Plans and Timelines Governments worldwide are actively responding to the potential massive disruption posed by quantum computers to existing cryptographic systems by formulating strategies forÂ migration to post-quantum cryptography (PQC).
As of mid-2025, more than 15 countries and regions have issued official guidance on PQC transition. Most follow the NIST (U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology) standardization process, while some develop indigenous algorithms independently. The general timeline for transition completion spansÂ 2027 to 2035, withÂ 2030Â considered a critical milestone.
United States The U.S. has established the most comprehensive plan, including:
National Security Memorandum 10 (May 2022): Signed by President Biden, titledÂ â€œAdvancing Americaâ€™s Leadership in Quantum Computing While Mitigating Risks to Vulnerable Cryptographic Systemsâ€.
The goal is toÂ mitigate quantum risks as much as possible by 2035.
NIST Transition Deadlines:
Phasing outÂ RSA-2048 and ECC-256 by 2030, withÂ complete prohibition by 2035, while allowing hybrid classical-PQC schemes during the transition.
NSAâ€™s CNSA 2.0 Suite:
Requires software and network equipment upgrades byÂ 2030, with browsers and operating systems completing upgrades byÂ 2033.
Presidential Executive Order 14144 (January 2025):
â€œStrengthening National Cybersecurity Innovationâ€Â emphasizes collaboration with other nations and industry to encourage adoption of NISTâ€™s PQC standards.
United Kingdom The UKâ€™s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), part of GCHQ intelligence agency, published guidance inÂ March 2025Â outlining a three-phase transition plan:
By 2028: Identify cryptographic services needing upgrades and develop migration plans.
2028â€“2031: Prioritize upgrading critical systems and adapt according to PQC progress.
2031â€“2035: Complete full migration of systems and products to PQC.
The UK plan explicitly bases onÂ NIST standardsÂ and aligns withÂ IETF protocol standardization efforts.
European Union The EU drives its PQC roadmap through the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) Quantum-Safe Cryptography (QSC) working group, established in 2015:
Published quantum-safe migration guidelines [ETS20] and key establishment standards [ETS25];
Provides technical reports endorsingÂ NIST standardsÂ as well.
China China pursues a moreÂ independent and autonomous PQC development path.
In February 2025, theÂ Commercial Cryptography InstituteÂ launched the â€œNext Generation Commercial Cryptography Algorithms Programâ€ (NGCC) 1, developing domestic PQC algorithms aligned withÂ national security requirements.
China emphasizesÂ technological self-relianceÂ andÂ has not publicly released a detailed transition timeline.
Industry Progress in Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) SeveralÂ well-known companies relying on cryptography in their products or servicesÂ have already started migrating to post-quantum cryptography (PQC) solutions.
Cloudflare Date: October 2022
Cloudflare announced thatÂ all websites and APIs served through Cloudflare support a post-quantum hybrid key exchange mechanism.
Technical Details: This mechanism combines classical elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) with theÂ post-quantum Kyber algorithmÂ to form aÂ hybrid scheme.
Security Advantage: Attackers must break both ECC and Kyber algorithms simultaneously to compromise keys, significantly enhancing security.
Google Date: August 2023
Google announced that its Chrome browser started supporting aÂ post-quantum hybrid key generation mechanismÂ similar to Cloudflareâ€™s.
Motivation and Background: Google emphasized the urgency of updating TLS (Transport Layer Security) to use quantum-resistant session keys to preventÂ â€œHarvest Now, Decrypt Laterâ€Â attacks, i.e.,
Attackers collect encrypted data now and decrypt it later once universal quantum computers become available.
Signal Date: September 2023
Signal, a leading privacy-focused encrypted messaging app, announced addingÂ post-quantum security layersÂ to its communication encryption.
Implementation: IntroducedÂ CRYSTALS-Kyber post-quantum key encapsulation mechanism (KEM)Â atop its original ECC-based encryption to enhance security.
Apple Date: February 2024
Apple announced a new encryption protocolÂ PQ3Â designed for iMessage.
PQ3 Features:
Uses PQC forÂ initial key agreementÂ andÂ ongoing message exchange;
Supports automatic recovery mechanisms, enabling rapid restoration of security even if a key is compromised, thereby enhancing overall resilience.
Industry Trend Summary With PQC algorithms continuously standardized and maturing,Â an increasing number of companies will deploy PQC mechanisms, marking a shift from â€œexperimental defenseâ€ to â€œmainstream security requirement.â€
Why Choose a â€œHybrid Encryptionâ€ Strategy? No single PQC algorithm is yet proven 100% secure;
Hybrid schemes allow aÂ gradual transition without interrupting existing security guarantees;
They prevent a â€œsingle point of failureâ€ â€” even if one algorithm is broken in the future, the other may still provide protection.
Why Kyber? Kyber is theÂ first post-quantum key encapsulation algorithm (KEM) standardized by NIST;
Based onÂ lattice cryptography, currently regarded as highly resilient to quantum attacks;
Has relatively small key and ciphertext sizes, making it suitable for performance-sensitive applications such as TLS and mobile communications.
Drivers for Industry Action Clear government timelines (e.g., NISTâ€™s 2030/2035 plans) create regulatory pressure;
Quantum threats may not be immediate, butÂ data harvesting attacks are already ongoing, requiring early preparation to protect future privacy;
Companies gain a first-mover advantage in security and can strengthen market trust.
Philosophical Debate If aÂ universal, breakable quantum computerÂ eventually becomes reality, the Bitcoin community will face a difficult decision:
Should it take action to handle currently exposed public-key UTXOs that are vulnerable to quantum attacks?
This question fundamentally touches Bitcoinâ€™s core values, such asÂ property rights, censorship resistance, forward compatibility,Â andÂ conservatism.
The â€œBurnâ€ Position Core Arguments By â€œburningâ€ quantum-vulnerable UTXOs, these coins become unusable, therebyÂ protecting property rights and network integrity.
Bitcoin developer Jameson Lopp2 , in his article [â€œAgainst Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoinâ€ (Lop25a)] and BDML talks, argues:
Allowing quantum computers to seize these bitcoins results in a wealth transferâ€”fromÂ those who lost keystoÂ winners of the quantum arms race.
The â€œburnâ€ strategy treats quantum vulnerability as aÂ protocol-level bugÂ that should be conservatively fixed, like previous vulnerabilities.
Economic Effects â€œBurningâ€ reduces total Bitcoin supply, therebyÂ increasing the value of remaining coins.
Coordinated â€œburnâ€ events canÂ reduce market uncertainty and volatility.
The â€œStealâ€ Position Core Arguments Opponents of â€œburningâ€ argue:
ItÂ violates user property rightsÂ and amounts to confiscation.
Bitcoinâ€™s design intent isÂ complete user sovereignty over their assets, allowing spending at any time.
Some users may be unaware of quantum risks or unable to migrate assets promptly.
Moral and Technical Dilemmas Protocol changes that render some UTXOs permanently unspendable introduceÂ third-party control, violating Bitcoinâ€™s decentralization principles.
Without intervention, the â€œstealâ€ path becomes theÂ default optionâ€”once quantum computers mature, early attackers could seize all vulnerable assets, causing seriousÂ wealth redistribution.
Migration Pathways Overview Migrating Bitcoin to quantum-resistant signatures is one of the most historically significant undertakings in the Bitcoin ecosystem. Even if a quantum-safe signature scheme gains technical consensus and integrates into Bitcoin Core, migrating millions of UTXOs to quantum-safe scripts requires unprecedented network coordination. This section discusses practical migration pathways, on-chain resource requirements, activation methods, user education, and coordination mechanisms3.
Quantum-resistant migration is not only a technical challenge but also aÂ network-wide collaboration and governance issue.
It involvesÂ block space, soft forks, user key management, activation mechanisms, and more.
All Bitcoin holders need basic awareness of migration pathways to develop effective risk mitigation strategies against quantum threats.
UTXO Migration As of May 2025, Bitcoinâ€™s UTXO set contains approximately 190 million UTXOs. Only a portion exposes public keys and is thus vulnerable toÂ long-range attacks. However, all UTXOs are potentially susceptible toÂ short-range attacksduring spending and transaction confirmation windows, as described earlier in â€œOn-Spend Vulnerable Script Types.â€
Ideally,Â all UTXOsÂ should migrate to quantum-resistant scripts by spending old UTXOs in a transaction and creating new UTXOs secured by post-quantum signatures. In practice, some UTXOs are inaccessible (e.g., lost keys), creating the â€œphilosophical dilemma: burn or steal.â€
2024 research estimates:
Theoretical fastest migration time: Using 100% block space for migration transactions, migrating all UTXOs would take approximately 76â€“142 days (model-dependent).
Realistic scenario: Using only 25% block space, it would take 305â€“568 days.
In reality, only an urgent migration ofÂ exposed public-key UTXOsÂ is necessary.
Key points:
UTXO migration is resource-intensive and costly.
Without on-chain scaling, existingÂ block size and block intervalÂ severely limit migration throughput.
Signature aggregationÂ andÂ batching transactionsÂ are potential optimizations.
Migration Mechanisms Several proposed mechanisms balanceÂ user participation, consensus rule changes, and technical complexity.
Commit-Delay-Reveal Protocol (CDR) and Variants Background:
Initially proposed in 2018, with variants by Adam Back, Tim Ruffing, and others.
Designed to securely migrate old UTXOs to post-quantum scripts even after ECC compromise.
Three-phase process:
Commit phase:
User creates a commitment transaction hashing the old ECC and new post-quantum public keys.
The hash is committed on-chain viaÂ OP_RETURN.
Transaction valid under current consensus rules.
Soft fork needed to enforce that the UTXO can only be spent by knowledge of both private keys.
Delay phase:
Introduces a mandatory delay period (e.g., 6 months) to prevent reorg attacks by ensuring chain finality.
Funds are locked and unusable during this period.
Reveal phase:
User submits a reveal transaction disclosing the original ECC and new post-quantum keys.
The transaction is signed with the post-quantum signature.
Verifies that the reveal matches the commit hash.
Advantages:
High security under CRQC presence; allows safe migration of unexposed UTXOs post-ECC compromise.
Supports migration after quantum attacks occur.
Disadvantages:
Cannot migrate UTXOs with already exposed public keys (e.g., P2PK).
Requires user participation in two transactions.
Requires users to hold post-quantum coins for fees, creating aÂ bootstrapping problem.
At least one, more likely two soft forks needed (one for PQ signatures, one for CDR semantics).
Block space constraints remain.
Improved Scheme: Lifted FawkesCoin Protocol Improvements:
Resolves the â€œuser must already hold PQ coinsâ€ problem in original CDR.
EmploysÂ zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs)Â using theÂ PICNICÂ PQ signature to prove knowledge of a private key without revealing the public key.
Circumvents the paradox of needing to reveal a public key to commit.
Additional capabilities:
HD wallet users can prove derivation relationships using seeds.
Partial private key loss is recoverable via master seed.
Can protect the majority of Bitcoin accumulated since HD wallets became standard.
Costs and challenges:
Requires integrating ZKPs into Bitcoin protocol, a more disruptive change than single PQ signature adoption.
PICNIC and related ZK systems are complex and not yet widely deployed.
Commentary & Opinion Bitcoinâ€™s quantum-resistant migration is aÂ gradual but urgentÂ process:
Comprehensiveness vs Reality:
Ideally migrate all UTXOs.
Practically prioritize active, spendable, high-risk UTXOs.
Inaccessible funds (lost keys) remain a â€œphilosophical problem.â€
Technical vs Social Coordination:
Technical solutions (CDR, ZKP lifting) are early-stage and require extensive validation.
Real challenges lie inÂ activation, education, consensus coordination, and incentive design.
Future research directions:
DesignÂ quantum-resistant coin creation mechanismsÂ to solve bootstrapping.
Simplify CDR workflows (e.g., automated wallet support).
ExploreÂ soft-fork-free or incremental transition mechanisms.
Analyze Groverâ€™s algorithm effectiveness on various Bitcoin script structures to inform prioritization.
References Institute of Commercial Cryptography Standards, China. Announcement on Launching the Next-generation Commercial Cryptographic Algorithms Program (NGCC). February 5, 2025. ↩︎
J. Lopp. Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin. Cypherpunk Cogitations. March 16, 2025. ↩︎
Chaincode Labs. Bitcoin and Quantum Computing: Current Status and Future Directions. ↩︎

title: Post-Quantum Readiness in Blockchain - Threats, Roadmaps, and Migration Strategy II

content:
Bitcoin’s Security and the Threat from Quantum Computing Bitcoin’s security relies on aÂ cryptographic assumption that has long been considered unbreakable under current technological conditions. However, the emergence of quantum computersÂ could undermine this assumption within the next decade.
At the core of Bitcoinâ€™s cryptographic foundation are:
theÂ Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA);
and, since 2021, the introduction ofÂ Schnorr signatures.
Both schemes are based on theÂ Elliptic Curve Discrete Logarithm Problem (ECDLP), which isÂ asymmetricÂ in nature: deriving the public key from a private key is easy, but reversing the process is believed to require trillions of years even on todayâ€™s most powerful supercomputers.
However, in the face ofÂ cryptographically relevant quantum computers (CRQCs), this asymmetry may collapse â€”Â deriving the private key from the public key could take only hours or days.
Institutions such as theÂ U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), theÂ U.S. government, and other international agencies have recommendedÂ phasing out elliptic curve cryptography by 2030Â andÂ fully deprecating it by 2035.
Potential Impact of Quantum Computers on Bitcoin Once practical quantum computers become available, their impact on Bitcoin could be profound. According to an analysis by 1:
ApproximatelyÂ 20% to 50% of all circulating Bitcoin (4 to 10 million BTC)Â could be at risk of theft;
This risk primarily stems from the ability toÂ derive private keys from exposed public keys.
The most vulnerable assets include:
UTXOs that useÂ insecure script types;
Funds associated withÂ â€œaddress reuseâ€, where the public key has already been revealed;
Exchange and institutional addressesÂ that frequently reuse addresses;
Early-era addresses from the Satoshi period, such as those using raw public key scripts;
â€œLost coinsâ€, which remain unmoved and are locked under outdated or unsafe scripts.
Among these,Â high-value exchange and institutional accountsÂ are expected to beÂ top targets for quantum-enabled attackers.
Quantum Threats to Bitcoin Mining and Ecosystem Security On the other hand, while quantum computing may also impactÂ Bitcoin mining, its threat isÂ considered limited in the foreseeable future:
Current mining performance is primarily driven byÂ clock frequency;
Quantum miners would have toÂ compete with highly optimized ASIC machines;
Even with aÂ quadratic speedupÂ from algorithms likeÂ Groverâ€™s, it would still be difficult to outperform classical miners;
TheÂ hardware performance gap remains significant.
If quantum miners were to dominate in the future, potential risks could include:
Double-spending attacksÂ by small or solo miners;
Increased centralizationÂ due to disproportionate mining power.
Although these scenarios remain distant, exploringÂ post-quantum mining modelsÂ still holds theoretical value and can help prepare for long-term contingencies.
Beyond Signatures and Mining: Ecosystem-Level Risks In addition to the direct threats toÂ digital signaturesÂ andÂ mining, a broader set ofÂ ecosystem-level vulnerabilitiesÂ must also be considered in the post-quantum era:
For example:Â SSL/TLS communication protocols,Â hardware wallets, andÂ firmware update mechanismsÂ may all be compromised by quantum-capable adversaries. Two Types of Quantum Attack Vectors (Long-Range Attack vs. Short-Range Attack)
Long-Range Attack: Targets addresses whoseÂ public keys are already exposed on-chain, such as P2PK, P2MS, and P2TR. These addresses areÂ permanently vulnerable, as their public keys are visible at all times.
Short-Range Attack: Targets addresses thatÂ only reveal their public keys when spending, such as P2PKH. In this case, the attacker must act within aÂ very short windowÂ â€” between the time a transaction is broadcast (and the public key is exposed) and when it gets confirmed on the blockchain.
In short,Â if the public key of a UTXO is known, quantum adversaries may derive the private key and steal the funds. The difference lies inÂ how and when the public key is exposed:
Some addresses areÂ â€œnatively exposedâ€, meaning their public keys are visible from the beginning, and thus remain underÂ long-term attack risk.
Others (e.g., P2PKH)Â only reveal the public key when the coin is spent, offering aÂ very narrow attack window, also known as aÂ “preemptive” or “racing” attack.
Quantum Vulnerabilities by Script Type The feasibility of quantum attacks depends not only on the existence of CRQCs (Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computers), but also on whether the correspondingÂ public key is accessible. Therefore, different script types present different levels of vulnerability. Below is a classification by script type:
ğŸ”´ Immediate Vulnerability P2PK (Pay to Public Key): The earliest script type, which directly exposes the ECDSA public key in the locking script. Though it accounts for only ~0.025% of UTXOs, it securesÂ ~8.68% of all BTC (~1.72 million BTC)Â â€” largely associated with early Satoshi-era wallets.
P2MS (Pay to MultiSig): A script type that exposes multiple public keys. Now rarely used and secures a relatively small amount of BTC.
P2TR (Pay to Taproot): Despite being a modern script, itsÂ key-path spending still reveals a tweaked public key, making it vulnerable to quantum attacks. P2TR makes up ~32.5% of UTXOs but secures only ~0.74% of BTC.
ğŸŸ¡ On-Spend Vulnerable Script Types P2PK, P2MS, and P2TR are classified asÂ â€œimmediately vulnerableâ€Â because they expose public keys directly in the output script (scriptPubKey).
However, some script typesÂ do not reveal the public key until the coin is spent. These are vulnerable only during the short windowÂ between transaction broadcast and confirmation.
ğŸŸ  Address Reuse Vulnerability Script types such asÂ P2PKH,Â P2SH,Â P2WPKH, andÂ P2WSHÂ only expose public keysÂ at the time of spending, meaning the key is normally revealed once.
But if the same address (i.e., the same public key) isÂ reused, the associated public key remainsÂ permanently exposedÂ on-chain, turning aÂ short-range attackÂ surface into aÂ long-range attackÂ vector.
ğŸŸ£ Other Avenues for Public Key Exposure 1. Fork Chain Exposure If a user spends an unspent UTXO on aÂ Bitcoin fork chainÂ (e.g., Bitcoin Cash, Bitcoin Gold), the public key becomes exposed on the fork â€” even though the UTXO remains unspent on the Bitcoin mainnet.
Thus, the corresponding UTXO on the mainnet becomes aÂ long-term quantum target.
2. Leaked Extended Public Keys (xpubs) xpubsÂ are used inÂ Hierarchical Deterministic (HD) wallets, enabling address generation without revealing private keys.
If anÂ xpubÂ is leaked, allÂ non-hardened child public keysÂ derived from it can have theirÂ private keys recoveredÂ by quantum computers.
3. Public Key Exposure in Multi-Sig & Lightning Network InÂ multi-signature walletsÂ andÂ Lightning NetworkÂ channels, participants must share their public keys to construct transactions or payment channels.
Although these public keys are not broadly public, they areÂ shared within limited parties, and thus may beÂ exploited by insiders or malicious actors.
Ecosystem Vulnerabilities OnceÂ elliptic curve cryptography (ECC)Â is broken by quantum computers, the impact will go far beyond Bitcoin â€” potentially compromising theÂ entire Internet cryptographic infrastructure.
Core protocols likeÂ SSL/TLSÂ could become insecure, leading toÂ ecosystem-level attacksÂ such asÂ man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, where adversaries intercept and redirect user requests:
MITM attacks: By compromising SSL/TLS, attackers can forge connections to exchanges andÂ hijack funds.
Hardware wallet updates: Firmware updates may beÂ tampered with, silently embedding backdoors.
Mining pool impersonation: Attackers mayÂ masquerade as minersÂ to infiltrate mining pools.
DNS attacks: Redirecting users toÂ malicious nodesÂ through DNS manipulation.
API attacks: Tampering with third-party APIs widely used byÂ wallets and exchanges.
These threats areÂ stealthier than direct cryptographic breakage, potentially remaining undetected for extended periods due to theirÂ ecosystem-level obfuscation.
Bitcoin Hash Functions and Groverâ€™s Algorithm Bitcoin relies on two hash functions:Â SHA-256Â andÂ RIPEMD-160, used for:
Mining (double SHA-256 on block headers)
Generating transaction IDs
Signing messages
Deriving addresses from public keys (Hash160)
Quantum Resistance of Hash Functions The fundamental property of hash functions isÂ irreversibility.
Even the worldâ€™s most powerful supercomputers (e.g.,Â El Capitan, as of Nov 2024) would require far more time to break them than to crack ECC. 2
Groverâ€™s algorithmÂ offers aÂ quadratic speedupÂ for brute-forcing hash functions:
Classical attack complexity:Â O(N)O(N)
Quantum attack complexity:Â O(N)O(Nâ€‹)
For example,Â finding a SHA-256 collisionÂ classically requiresÂ 22562256Â operations.
With Groverâ€™s algorithm, this is reduced toÂ 21282128, which is still computationally infeasible withoutÂ extremely powerful quantum computer.
Impact on Bitcoin Mining The essence of Bitcoin mining is toÂ find a nonce valueÂ that makes the block header’s hash lower than the network difficulty target.
This process involves repeatedÂ SHA-256 computations, currently performed almost exclusively byÂ ASIC hardware.
1.Â Limitations of Quantum Mining Groverâ€™s algorithm provides sequential, not parallel, speedup, which leads to key limitations:
ItÂ cannot scale in parallelÂ like classical mining does; adding more quantum hardware doesÂ not linearly increasehash power.
Competing with ASICs would requireÂ a large number of high-speed quantum machines, making deploymentÂ extremely costly.
2. Network Difficulty Adjustment Bitcoin dynamically adjusts its mining difficultyÂ every 2016 blocksÂ to maintain a block interval of ~10 minutes.
If quantum mining is introduced, the protocol willÂ increase the difficulty accordingly, which would furtherÂ offset any advantageÂ from Groverâ€™s algorithm.
Forks and the 51% Attack 1.Â Quantum-Induced Forking Risk Research shows that quantum mining couldÂ increase the frequency of blockchain forks:
When one miner finds a valid block, other quantum miners must decide whether toÂ continue or restart their computation.
Simultaneous quantum measurementsÂ by multiple miners increase the chance thatÂ multiple valid blocks are found at the same time, causingÂ forks.
2.Â Security Concerns In a high-fork environment:
Honest miners’ hash power getsÂ split across multiple chains;
Adversaries canÂ concentrate their resourcesÂ on attacking one chain, potentially gaining dominanceÂ without owning 51% of total hash power.
This reducesÂ finalityÂ andÂ consensus stability, and significantlyÂ increases the attack surface.
Comprehensive Quantum Vulnerability Assessment of Bitcoin Component Quantum Threat Resistance Level ECC Signatures Critical riskÂ (Shor’s algorithm) Very Low Hash Functions Moderate riskÂ (Grover’s algorithm) Relatively High Mining Mechanism Efficiency impacted but adjustable Medium Ecosystem Attacks High riskÂ (SSL, DNS, APIs) Depends on external mitigation Fork Security Potentially severeÂ (more frequent forks) Low References Chaincode Labs. content:
â“What is Quantum Computing? Quantum computing harnesses the quantum states of microscopic particlesâ€”such as photons, electrons, or atomsâ€”to process information. It is fundamentally based on several key principles:Â superposition,Â entanglement,Â coherence, and theÂ no-cloning theorem.
As early asÂ 1982,Â Professor Richard FeynmanÂ famously stated:
“Nature isnâ€™t classical, damn it, and if you want to make a simulation of nature, youâ€™d better make it quantum mechanical.”
This insight laid the conceptual foundation for building computational tools using quantum systems themselves, rather than relying on classical approximations of quantum behavior.
Why Classical Computers Are Not Enough Many fundamental systems in nature do not follow classical physics but are governed by quantum mechanics. Therefore, if we want to â€œsimulate nature,â€ classical computation is not sufficient â€” we must use quantum systems themselves to build computational tools.
More specifically, simulating quantum systems with classical computers faces exponential difficulty. A quantum system composed ofÂ $n$Â particles requiresÂ $2^n$Â complex numbers to describe its state, which quickly exceeds the processing capability of classical machines. Furthermore, particles in a quantum system are often not independent â€” they form complex correlations known asÂ quantum entanglement.
Quantum computing, on the other hand, leverages the superposition of quantum states to perform parallel computation. For example, a 4-qubit quantum register can represent all 16 values from 0 to 15 simultaneously, and any operation on the register acts on all 16 values at once.
This is why Feynman proposed a groundbreaking idea: instead of simulating quantum systems with classical computers, we should use quantum systems themselves to compute. His insight was remarkably accurate â€” as we now know, there are computations that can only be carried out through quantum experiments and are beyond the reach of traditional computers.
What Does Quantum Computing Mean for Mainstream Cryptosystems Like RSA and ECC? In 1994, Peter Shor proposed a quantum algorithmâ€”Shor’s Algorithmâ€”that can break mainstream cryptosystems such as RSA and ECC, drawing widespread attention. The foundation of Shor’s Algorithm is its ability to perform fast Fourier transforms (FFT) on state vectors of exponential size, making it easier to identify the period of a function.
Quantum computing leverages the superposition effect of quantum states, allowing parallel computation across all possible states. For example, SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s cat can be simultaneously â€˜aliveâ€™ and â€˜deadâ€™â€”a superposition of two states. If there are 100 cats, each in a superposition of â€˜aliveâ€™ and â€˜deadâ€™ there are ($2^{100}$) possible states. Each state has its own amplitude, positive or negative, and quantum computing can manipulate this exponentially large vector of states simultaneously.
On the surface, this exponential parallelism might seem to allow brute-force solutions to any computationally hard problem. However, the output of a quantum computation is itself a superposition, making it difficult to extract a definitive answer.
Currently, only Shorâ€™s Algorithm can use quantum Fourier transforms to efficiently extract the period of a function, thereby solving the integer factorization and discrete logarithm problems upon which modern public-key cryptosystems RSA and ECC are based. For other hard problems that cannot be reduced to period finding, no polynomial-time quantum algorithms are known yet.
How Close Are We to Practical Quantum Computers? Yes and no. To break a 1024-bit RSA key, a universal quantum computer with millions of qubits would be neededâ€”far beyond our current manufacturing capabilities (the largest quantum computers today have only a few hundred qubits):
In 2017, IBM introduced the worldâ€™s first 16-qubit quantum computer. The latest fault-tolerant universal quantum machines, such as Googleâ€™s Willow chip (105 qubits by the end of 2024), now achieve error correction threshold capabilities. The Oxford team has also created single-qubit operations with gate error rates as low as 0.000015%. Developing public-key cryptographic algorithms that can resist quantum attacks (post-quantum cryptography) has become an urgent task. To address this, the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) launched the Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) standardization project back in 2016. After years of evaluation, the leading quantum-resistant public-key algorithmsâ€”such as CRYSTALS-Kyber, Dilithium, and Falconâ€”are now essentially standardized and are set to become the new benchmarks for federal and enterprise security infrastructure.
D-Waveâ€™s Progress The Canadian quantum computing companyÂ D-WaveÂ has long providedÂ quantum annealers, which are well-suited for solvingÂ optimization problems, rather than problems likeÂ period-findingÂ as required byÂ Shorâ€™s algorithm.
InÂ 2025, D-Wave released itsÂ Advantage2Â system, featuringÂ over 4,400+ qubitsÂ and aÂ 20-node connectivity topology. It is currently offering cloud-based services to clients such asÂ Mastercard,Â NTT, and theÂ JÃ¼lich Supercomputing Centre.
Meanwhile, D-Waveâ€™s team published a paper inÂ ScienceÂ claimingÂ â€œquantum advantageâ€Â for the first time: in simulating complex magnetic systems, their machine outperformed the worldâ€™s top classical supercomputers by what they claim would beÂ millions of years.
Although this result has sparked debates over classical simulators (such asÂ MPSÂ andÂ t-VMC), it still suggests thatÂ quantum annealingÂ is showingÂ practical valueÂ in certain scientific and engineering domains.
D-Wave has built and sold several quantum computers; however, these machinesÂ cannot run Shorâ€™s algorithmÂ and thereforeÂ do not pose a direct threat to cryptographic schemes based on factoring or discrete logarithms.
Strictly speaking, D-Wave buildsÂ quantum annealers, which are machines that canÂ only run quantum annealing algorithms. Their fundamental working principle differs from that ofÂ universal quantum computers, which rely on quantum superposition to achieve powerful computational capabilities. In contrast, quantum annealers rely onÂ quantum tunnelingÂ to simulate the annealing process.
Currently, there is research underway that attempts to transformÂ integer factorizationÂ into anÂ annealing-compatible problemÂ and solve it using D-Wave machines â€” but so far, it has only managed to factorÂ integers up to 90 bits.
Emerging Track: Topological Quantum Computing and Fault-Tolerance February 2025:Â MicrosoftÂ launched its firstÂ Majorana-based topological quantum processor,Â Majoranaâ€¯1, featuring highly stable topological qubits and aiming forÂ million-qubit scalability.
May 2025:Â QuantinuumÂ announced that itsÂ H2 systemÂ had achieved a record-breakingÂ quantum volume $2^{23}=8388608$, a key metric for assessing a systemâ€™s practical computational power.
May 2025:Â Oxford,Â Googleâ€™s Willow, and other teams continued advancing toward fault-tolerant quantum computing by optimizingÂ single-qubit gate fidelitiesÂ and improvingÂ two-qubit error correction schemes.

Throughout the evolution of human civilization, the pursuit of computational power has never ceased. From $\underline{mechanical ~computation}$ to $\underline{electronic ~computation}$, we now stand at the dawn of a new era â€” $\mathbf{on ~the ~verge ~of ~quantum ~computing. }$
The core breakthrough of quantum computing does not lie in macro-level advancements such as â€œfasterâ€ transistors or â€œstrongerâ€ chips, but rather in a paradigm shift from macro to micro: it no longer relies on the classical binary of 0 and 1 but leverages the peculiar properties of quantum superposition and entanglement at the particle level to build $\underline{an ~entirely ~new ~computational ~logic}$. This logic cannot be simulated by traditional electronic computers, much like nuclear weapons cannot be replicated with chemical explosivesâ€”their energies are simply not on the same scale.
In this age of exponentially increasing computational power, modern cryptography stands as the first field to be fundamentally challenged. Encryption algorithms that are rock-solid on classical computersâ€”such as RSA and ECCâ€”become vulnerable in the face of quantum algorithms like Shorâ€™s algorithm.
Just as electronic computers once marked the end of the mechanical cipher era, quantum computing is now poised to reshape the foundations of modern cryptography. It brings not only challenges, but also an opportunity to redefine what â€œsecurityâ€ truly means.
